intro: Suaeda ampullacea, commonly known as the saltbush, is a flowering plant native to arid and coastal regions of the Middle East, North Africa, and the Arabian Peninsula. It is a halophyte, meaning it thrives in saline environments, often found in salt marshes and coastal dunes. The plant has small, fleshy leaves that help reduce water loss, and its flowers are typically yellow or orange, appearing in clusters. It plays an important ecological role in stabilizing sandy soils and providing habitat for various insects and birds. Suaeda ampullacea is also used in traditional medicine and as a source of fodder for livestock.
